Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Grant: Coaching for Academic and Professional Success (CAPS) in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The implementation project entitled - Coaching for Academic and Professional Success in STEM - builds on a planning grant and has the goals to reinvigorate science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education at the Virginia Union University and significantly increase the number of graduates that compete successfully for admission into graduate programs and/or the STEM workforce. The main objectives of this project are to increase recruitment, retention, and graduation rates in all STEM disciplines by at least 50% within the next five years while maintaining the academic rigor that is required for student success after graduation. Three strategic initiatives are designed to meet the objectives: (1) the establishment of a STEM Summer Institute that improves the preparedness of rising freshmen for college; (2) the implementation of high-impact educational practices across the STEM curricula, and (3) the establishment of a STEM Coaching Team.

While the strategies implemented in this project will improve STEM education at Virginia Union University, it is anticipated that they will be equally effective at other small liberal arts institutions and that this project can serve as a national model. The project emphasizes the importance of close relationships between undergraduate STEM programs, high schools, graduate institutions, and employers of STEM graduates, and, consequently, will enhance the mission of each of these partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coaching for Academic and Professional Success in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (CAPS in STEM)

This project aimed to increase undergraduate recruitment, retention, and graduation rates in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines at Virginia Union University, a small, private, historically black college in Richmond, Virginia. To achieve the project goals, three strategic initiatives were developed: 1) the implementation of high-impact educational practices across STEM disciplines, 2) the establishment of a summer enrichment program for rising freshmen, and 3) the establishment of a STEM Career Coaching Team. 

Mean enrollment of STEM majors during the 2011-2018 project period was 26.1% higher than the mean enrollment of students during the 2009-2011 baseline period. Recruitment of Biology majors, i.e., the mean number of first-time first-year students entering the Biology major, increased by 29.8%, but these gains were offset by declines in the recruitment of Chemistry, Mathematics, and Computer Information Systems (CIS) majors. Similarly, the first-year retention rate of Biology majors during the project period was on average 21.5% higher than during the baseline period, but again this gain was offset by decreases in the Chemistry, Mathematics, and CIS. Only the Biology major saw a substantial increase (33.5%) in the four-year graduation rate. STEM students who visited a Career Coach at least once during academic years 2016-2017 and 2017-2018 were more likely to have higher cumulative GPAs after their first year and more likely to graduate in four years, relative to peers who did not visit a Career Coach. 

Lessons learned during the project period suggest that some of the project activities will be more effective if modifications are made to their original design. For example, student attendance to weekly seminars with a career focus and student visits with a STEM Career Coach were voluntary and making these activities mandatory by incorporating them in the standard curriculum in all likelihood will increase their impact on student success. Similarly, expansion of the summer enrichment program throughout the four-year enrollment period in all likelihood will enhance student engagement. 

It is recognized that recruitment, retention, and graduation rates depend on additional factors, other than those addressed by the three strategic initiatives of this project. While for various reasons general enrollment numbers at VUU fluctuated during the project period, total enrollment in the STEM disciplines remained relatively constant and showed a gradual increase in the Biology major, suggesting a positive effect of the project activities. 

Two aspects of the supported project have now been institutionalized in modified formats: 1) summer enrichment activities for rising freshmen (strategic initiative 2 listed above) have influenced establishment of a month-long New Student Orientation program for all VUU students, both STEM and non-STEM majors, with the goal to improve college preparedness for all rising freshmen; and 2) STEM Career Coaching activities (strategic initiative 3 listed above) have influenced establishment of the Virginia Union Center for STEM Diversity with the goal to continue efforts to provide specific career guidance and extracurricular support to all STEM majors.  

Lastly, during the project period, faculty development with respect to high-impact educational practices focused on the establishment of authentic research projects on campus and this has begun to produce course-based undergraduate research experiences for Biology majors. Furthermore, the CAPS in STEM project has positively influenced the establishment of separately funded faculty research projects, as well as the establishment of a new Physics major, a new Physics/Engineering dual degree program, and a new Cybersecurity major. These research activities and new majors are anticipated to have a positive impact on future recruitment, retention, and graduation rates in the STEM disciplines.
